climbs.name: Rocks On! Rocks On! Rocks On!

content.description:
This variation of the climb allows the use of the rocks in the crack. The start is almost the end of the crack, or as far in as you feel comfortable. It goes all the way up it and tops out with the rock coming out from the left. This variation allows for a gnarly foot jam at the start utilizing one of the smaller rocks inside the crack. 

  Note: the small rocks in the crack are pretty sturdy, not that it would take a lot to get them out.
content.location: This climb is the crack on the far left of the Overshadowed Boulder. There are a lot of small rocks in the crack.

climbs.name: Rocks Off! Rocks Off! Rocks Off!

content.description: This climb allows does not  allow for the use of the rocks in the crack. The start is almost the end of the crack, or as far in as you feel comfortable. It goes all the way up it and tops out with the rock coming out from the left.
content.location: This ascends the furthest left crack on Overshadowed Boulder.

content.description: Last Chance is a really fun, topout problem that is short but really technical. Make sure to try out different ways to do it, as there is many sequences that will work.
content.protection: The landing is really bad - it is rocky and goes downhill, maybe get a few spotters along with pads.
content.location: Start standing with your hands on the lip on a hold just over the jagged looking crimp of Bear Claw with your left hand on a sloper and your right hand on a good sidepull next to it. Pull on, and find a way to top out. You can either go straight up to a small crimp slot or move left to a big sloper.

content.description: This is one of the harder climbs at Wilson Reservation. This starts in the Overshadowed Boulder on the right side. It starts on a crimp and an okay sidepull thing. You are able to get a far heel out to the left and a toe directly under the start in the cave. You go up to a crimp, then match on it. After that, there is a crimp out of the over hang which allows you to grab the top, which isn't amazing, and top it out.
content.location: It is on the right side of Overshadowed Boulder.

content.description: Start on a jug in the center of the cave but on the lip. Traverse right along the lip, and top out as far right as you can. The topout is a little awkward.
content.location: Start on a jug ledge on the lip of the cave, and traverse rightward.

content.description: This is a really good lip traverse with big moves on good holds and a tricky topout.
content.protection: Pads, the landing can be bad in a few spots.
content.location: Start all the way on the left side of the boulder with both of your hands on a good edge that is in a crack. Make big moves out right along the lip on mostly good holds until you get to a good jug all the way on the right side of the cliff. Do a tricky topout/mantel that is technical but fun.

content.description: This climb is the hardest climb in all of Wilson Reservation. It starts on the same start as Hot Heels and goes left on some heinous crimps. It then goes up to the better of the crimps, or the bear claw. Then it goes to the top.
content.location: Start on Hot Heels which is to the right of the rock.

content.description: This is good almost any time. It has a super awesome overhang with some insane routes in there. Some are crazy hard, and some are just dumb fun. This is one of the weirdest rock at Wilson Mt. and has potential for the hardest routes there. This is a must see even if you aren't going to climb on it, and even if you can't climb V7 it's still super cool just to try!
